div.p: THE PROLOCVTOVR, OR, A Preparative for PEACE.
Printed in the Yeer. 1648.

div.head: THE PROLOCVTOVR, OR, A Preparative for Peace.
div.p: SHall the Sword devour for ever? 2 Sam. 2.26. no; Oh thou Sword of the Lord, how long will it be ere thou ceaze? turn againe into thy scabbard, rest, and be still. Ier. 47.6. For many which never saw a man wounded, much lesse slaine, now in the midst of wounds, and death, how can they but stand appalled? To behold a particular man kill himself, would daunt a tender heart; who can then but faint to see a whol Nation draw upon it self? Whence are Warres and Contentions? are they not hence, even from the lusts that fight in your Members? 4 Iames. 1. Are there not some distempered affections amongst us? is there not a popular phrenzy? Yes, Quis furor oh cives? The Kingdome is like to give herself the deadly stabbe, and to prove felo de se. It is an act of charity then, and naturall compassion, to hold your hands, nay to endeavour to take the weapons out of your hands, for quae tanta licentia ferri? But how shall we compose this difference, pacify this rage? Nature (me thinks) might doe much to appease this quarrell, policy more, religion most of all.

Nature, for Nature which is a conserver of her self, and hath taken upon her to be the Squire of the body to defend a being, will that suffer you to commit such outrages? No, if ye would consult with Nature, that would shame you, confound you in this truculent Designe. Nature likes not to have any such mortall prizes playd upon her stage, Nature loves not the cut-throat:
Hath she then bred you, and fed you, skinned you smooth, and nou •• ed you gentle, seated courtesy in your browes, and humanity in your hearts, put you to school where you might learne so many principles of nature, and grounds of meekness, and mildness, now to prove so savage? There is a poor relique in such of Nature, yea little left of the man; No, the same creature is gone, and a wilde beast is stept up in the stead, man is become a Leopard or Tyger, for whilst ye are thus implacable, are ye not unnaturall? But the plea of Nature is yet stronger against you, when she hath bound you to Amity, and Vnity with firmer links, even of the same Country, and the same acquaintance, and the same kindred. All of you being of the same Country, most of you of the same acquaintance, many of you of the same kindred. And shall the thoughts of Country, acquaintance, kindred, now be laid aside, that ye may have the freet liberty to worke mutuall mischiefs? No, Country should prevaile with you for a Countriman is precious in Turkey, in the Indies; they which have travelled all parts, find that they will leave all to embrace a Country-man, to endeere themselves to a Country-man. And shall a Country-man be acceptable abroad, contemptible at home? have we forgotten the common soyle we tread upon, the common ayre we breath in? what pollute this soyle with our owne blood, corrupt this ayre with the dying gaspes of Natives? shall we foster a Countrey-man else-where, and braine him here? no, the name of Country should put more tender affections into us, into you. And for acquaintance, how doth it knit and combine? friends seem to incorporate, yea to inanimate one another, as if they had but the same flesh in severall pieces, yea the same soul to quicken many Individualls; for friends, what are they but so many multiplyed selves? deere and entire is the • ty of friendship, for a friend that is unto thee as thine own soul. 13 Deutr. 6. Friendship is ferrumen animarum, Naz. the folder of spirits, the cement of familiarity; acquaintance is the loadstone of the feet to draw them together, and the chiming of tongues to make one hammar, (as it were) to strike after another, for friends are never well till they be pacing, and parlying together; their brests are open, for no secrets amongst friends; their hearts spring, or faint at the presence or absence of one another,Bern. for sine quo vivere mori, without whom to live is to dye. A man will search the world
through for a friend, a friend is the gemme of price in this earthly cabinet. And shall not the thought of friends keep the age peaceable? what hold thy poll-axe over that head that hath devised so much good to thee! bend thy speare against that brest where liveth an heart that hath wished thee all true happiness! shall thy plundering horse neigh at that threshold, or thy keene sword glitter under that roof, where all manner of ki • dness hath been exprest! what, rifle the coffers, or cut the heart-strings of thy deerest friends? Oh that all courteous passages, and sweet interchanges of favour can be so soon forgotten! Nature here hath a strong accusation against thee for the neglect of acquaintance, that the friend should be made such a stranger. And what shall we say to kindred? The remembrance of kindred? The remembrance of kindred is a kind of enchantment unto Peace, for let there be no strife between thee and me, for we are brethren, 13 Gen. 8. If the consideration of pedigrees, that the same nest hath hatched them, or the same stock hath branched them forth will not keep men quiet, what can? Nature can do no more then carry you home to the same cradle that rocked you, or to the same brests that nourced you. Have your fathers sent you out of the same loynes, and your Mothers brought you forth out of the same wombe, to cleave and quarter one another, to prove such a Cadmus race? Oh if many of you could leave the forced titles of Voluntieres, Troopers, &c. and call your selves your Fathers children, to thinke that ye are derived from the same family, that that good old man that now lies mouldering under a gravestone, and consuming into gelly, left you all his owne name, that he gave you many a kisse in his life-time, that ye might be the loving children of the same Father; yea and gave you a dying charge, that for all the cost he had bestowed upon you, the care he had taken for you, the teares he had shed for you, the Armes and jewells he left you, that ye would for the honor of his blood, and out of reverence to his dying requests live in peace together, doubtless this would take downe your haughty resolutions, and quench your fiery expressions. For oh that ye should undermine the foundations of your owne families, pull downe the crefts of your owne Scutcheons, that where there hath be • n the infusion of the same blood, there should be now the effusion of the same blood; that kindred should be sundered; that Pedigree should
hew downe her owne fayre spreading tree, and not to leave her issue a branch to spring out of the old stock, that consanguinity should be turned into exanguinity! Oh ponder upon these things, and see how Nature intercedes for Peace, she beseecheth you by all those deere Remembrancers of hers ye carry about you, that ye would not renew these fatall strokes, for so long as ye continue these Warres, ye warre against Nature; Nature suffers in these things, and by these things ye will scarce at last leave any mention of Nature amongst you. She desireth you once more to heare her Solicitors; Ye are all Country-men, and shall Country-men be so fell and furious against one another? or shall the Country fall by the hands of her owne Champions, and Protectors? Ye are most of the same acquaintance, and shall acquaintance wax unkest and unkent? shall juratissimi amici prove juratissimi inimici? sworn friends turn vaved enemies? And to conclude, ye are many of you of the same kindred, and will ye march to the confusion of one another, through the bowells of your owne linage, through a deluge of blood gushing out of the warme springs of your own kindred? No, Country, acquaintance, kindred, forbid these things; Oh then that so long as ye feel Nature stirring in you, that ye can give the check to the impulsions of Nature! No, the Warres must ceaze, Nature hath adjudged them unlawfull.

Secondly Policy. For how can Policy approve of these Warres? no, true Policy is Secretary of State to that great Empresse of the whole world, called Politcy. Policy then will never like of those things that she seeth work to the destruction of Commonweales. Policy holds her self to her grounds, and these Warres, and her grounds are incompatible.

For first, a ground of Policy it is to maintaine Order. Let Order be destroyed, and the nerve of Policy is weakened, yea the Arch of it shattered, and demolished. What doth Policy more ayme at, then to keep men within their just measures, to reteine every one in their due degrees. If the Head once lose the impery, and command, all the members turne Male-contents, and are but like a company of unruly Generalls; Government is then confusion, and Order Faction; like the temper of Nature, let loose to the distemper of every severall humour, or a ship well guided, after the Master is over-mastered, left to the steering of
every unexperienced Boat-swaine. Take away Order, and take away the security of the Common-wealth, for this is the hinge of community, the publique Buttresse. If the Principall may not be obeyed, what Superiority will there be submitted to? no it is to extirpate, exregnate all authority, even for servants to rise up against their Masters, for children to pluck their Parents by the throat, for the Wife to destroy her Husband that lay by her sides, for the Peasant to kill the yeoman, the yeoman to murder the Gentleman, the Gentleman to shed the blood of the Knight, the Knight to stabbe the Nobleman, Societies to slaughter their super-Intendents. Incorporations to butcher their Magistrates, and in fine for the Commons to massacre Parliaments. For that which is denied to the Highest, will never be granted to men of inferior degree; no this spark is ready to set al in combustion, even to kindle a generall flame; for when Order is taken away, Anarchy succeeds, and what can we look for out of Anarchy, but for a clew of mischiefs? Oh therefore what are ye doing? even undoing the goodliest frame of Government under heaven; for whereas superiors formerly lived no where with more obeysance, now no where they shall live with more disdaigne; for the Hinde will scorne to be subject to the chief man in the Parish, and every despicable person with a sword by his side, and a Pistoll in his hand, will brave upon men worth hundreds, thousands. It is not the painted portall, nor the fitted gowne that will any longer beget awe; No, where the Prince is not reverenced, a generall disobedience runs through the whole Nation. If this were Policy therefore, Policy should have forgotten one of her chi • f State-Maximes, for how can she preserve States without Order? no, It is Gods mercy (even for want of this) that we are not all before this time, through some popular rage, buried in a common grave. Policy then even for this disclaimeth the Warre.

Secondly, It is a ground of Policy to worke her ends by fayre meanes. If she hath the best things in the world to undertake, she likes no acerbity in the carriage; no, Policy is the true Benefactor of the Common-Wealth, the great Statist, therefore she contrives all her publique well-fare by well-fare, that is, by placid and gentle passages. If there be any harmfull accidents here, the crafty Agent is suspected, not the true Politician, because
true policy never doth any grievous, damnifying things; No, Be wise as Serpents, but innocent as Doves. 10. Matt. 16. To bring in an Innovation then by violence, what is this but to contest with Policy? especially such a violence as makes the Nobles to deplume the Commons, and the Commons to eviscerate the Nobles, for men in gener • ll to fire Cities, and forrage fields, to make ships ly at anchor in the haven, and the wares to moath-cat in the shoppe, to melt all the plate of the Land into a Campe-fee, and that which the Providence of many Ages hath gathered together, to consume in a few yeers. Policy liketh not of Innovations with such weakening and wasting of Common-weales. Innovations she ever counts dangerous, but when they come to be compelled, mischievous; for if a Fabrick be out of frame, it must be new-settled with tenderness, or else a man may have the house on his head instead of repayring it; if the body be valetudinary, the Malignancy must be fetched away by degrees, lest in stead of purging out the evill humours, thou drawest out the vitall spirits. I will drive softly, (said Iacob) according to the pace of the cattell. 33 Gen. 14. lest in getting the drove home too fast, he might leave part of it dead by the way. He that wringeth the nose, forceth out blood. 30 Prov. 33. Fetch out the filth, but doe not force out blood; better leave some filth till another time, then to streine so hard, till thou openest the Orifices. Changes then must be wrought by the sweetness of Counsell, and the equity of things presented to the Vnderstanding, for if our judgement cannot apprehend the conveniency of a request, our great hearts will never yeeld to compulsion. The sword can never satisfy us, for the very shaking of that makes us rather obstinate, then tractable. If we be to doe all as our Prudence shall direct us, will we ever be taught Wisedome by the Battle-axe? No, the State allows no such engine of Policy for Princes. Policy, if she intend any Innovation, she will either incline it, or decline it; if she cannot viam invenire, she will not facere; no, she works all by faire means.

Thirdly, it is a ground of Policy to Remunerate; for that is not Policy that waxes unkind upon courtesies received, or bicker so soon as she is pleasured: No, t is were rather to be Tetricall than Politique; for what discreet person will quarrell upon a good turne received? Such a one should be like a Guest, that
challenges his Feast-maker, when he hath fed him with all his costly dainties. But the part of Policy is to cherish good Natures, and to honour Worth, even to stoop and cringe to Beneficence; yea the highest stretch of her devices, and the achme of her inventions, is to procure a remainder of Favours, by instilling her good opinion of those she hath received; for the Bark will come no more at that Port where it hath been arrested for bringing in commodities. Cessat gratiarum cursus ubi recursus non fuerit, Favours cease where Thankfulnesse failes. Oh then! when a Prince hath honoured a Nation with more acts of Grace then any of his Predecessors, eased many Grievances, parted with most of his Rights, complyed with his people in such high Demands; Is this a time to denounce Warre against Him? No, a man would think some Monument should be set up to His honour, or Pyramid of Gratitude erected, to immortalize His Name: These a man would expect, rather than a new Present of Iron-Bullets; this may seem State-greatnesse, but is is no Policy, because Policy loves to Remunerate.

Fourthly, it is a ground of Policy to live answerably to her own praescript Rules; for Policy is a heedy observer of her own Principles, and carryes a sacred reverence to her own Lawes, or else she should seem to put a mock upon the world, in commending the justnesse of them, or commanding obedience towards them: for it is the height of Iniquity to prescribe that to another, which we will not practise our selves. Oh then, when a Kingdome is secured by a Petition of Right, so that nothing should be taken of the Subject but by his own consent, to involve a State into such a War as cannot be maintained without forcing the estate, and constreine the consents, as if men would compell both Goods and Conscience to serve their ends (whereby the Nation that is ready to be called the Kingdome of Priviledges, is now ready to be called the Kingdome of Manacles) how inconsiderate should this be? for what worse than to bring in a War to batter down a peoples Immunities, or to vanquish their Liberties, whereby many free Subjects are so fast locked-up in Prison, that neither Magna Charta, nor the Petition of Right can get a Iayle-delivery for them? Oh what is now the benefit of Lawes? How are we freed from Arbitrary Government, even when the high-Court of Iustice is open?
Doubtlesse all the old Patriots stand agast, and the wisest Iudges are confounded, how to settle the Subject upon his ancient Basis, the Law. If a Prince hereafter mind to Tyrannize, here is little restraint for him; he may easily enter upon our common Rights, for the gap is broken for him; he may send Pursivants, and Serjeants at Armes, imprison, plunder, take the twentith part, set an Excise upon our meat, yea beget a breed of Taxes every New-Moon, and all this by a Parliament-license: Vnhappy Warre therefore, that would still ensl • ve all our Freedomes, and lay all our Lawes and Liberties a bleeding. Valour may like this War, and sunk faced Indigency, that knows not how to support her selfe but under the miseries of a decayed State, may magnify it, but true Policy will never approve of it, for this makes her live contrary to her prescript Rules.

Fiftly, it is a ground of Policy to preserve her owne Forces against a common Enemy, for as nature doth not enfeeble (as nigh as she can) her own strength, but keep that entire to resist the Enemies of Nature, so Policy doth not wreck upon her Worthies, and wast her Combatants in Civill Dissentions, but layes up these as the State-store to oppugne the publique Adversary. But by entring the Lists with a King, to leavy Armies, and send out numerous Hosts Cogere in ordinem to bring him to his knees; What is this but to unpeople a Country, and disarme a Kingdom against a National danger? For who may not defy us at our own doors, and put the yoak upon our necks, when we have scarce left men enough to fill our Garrisons, and meanes enough • o tigge out a Navy? Any daring Invader may then have his advantage: Oh, is this to make a Nation formidable? No, to rob a Nation of her courage, and prowesse, and leave nothing but cowardize to lift up her trembling undisciplined hands to repell an enemy. If we must needs have Wars, we might imploy our strength in doing honourable things to the Nation, and in filleting the browes of the State with a Wreath of Forreign Victories.

Hoc quem civiles hauserunt sanguine dextra!

div.p:
If our Zeale bee so hot, and Conscience calleth us up to the
Warres, we might go and pluck the Pope out of his Porphiry Chaire, or the Grand Signior out of his Saragli • , or Mount Pelion upon Ossa: Here are a company of such invincible Termagants lately arisen, that they feare neither Centaures nor Minotaures: Well, if their valour be so great, they might better make prooff of it any where, then in gashing the sides of their own Nation. For thus to lay all our magnanimous spirits gasping at home, whereby we are disabled to exercise puissance abroad, either to defend, or encrease the honour of the Nation; What is this but to pervert Valour, or (if we have wisdome to conceive it, and patience to heare it) insensibly to betray a State? Whatsoever stomack there may bee in it, there is little Policy; for Policy quiets all her home-bred Differences without a noise, and preserves her own Forces against a common Enemy.

So that Policy was never called into this Councell of Warre, no, if she must fight, she likes not to fight at this weapon, called Selfe-bleed. She is put by all her ingenious Plots, and rare Artifices, when she is drawn into approve of this War; if you would have the Cause countenanced therefore you must get some other Patron then Policy, for with all her Mercuriall wit she cannot find out one justifying reason for it; this Cause then as it is none of the kindest, for Nature dislikes it, so it is none of the wisest, for Policy disallows it; as it wants something of the breast for Affection, so it wants something of the braine for Iudgement; guilty of much State-frowardnesse, and as much State-folly; all Policies grounds here faile her, for this course is neither tender of order, nor faire in managing, nor sensible of favours, nor carefull to preserve her owne rules, or her owne Forces; whatsoever fancied Epithet therefore can be put upon the Designe, yet it cannot be called Politique; No, the Warres must cease, if Policy may give sentence.

But you will say the maine satisfaction is still behind; for though Nature and Policy have condemned the Enterprise, yet if Scripture will authorise it it shall be held lawfull. But if thou hast run with the Footmen and they have wearied thee, 12 Jer. 5. how then shalt thou run with the Horsmen? If Nature and Policy outstrip this fond apprehension, then how shall it keep pace with Scripture? Shall Scripture savour that course that Nature rejects, and Policy disclaimes? No, it were a marvaile, if men
could bring God into the combination, and make him head of the Faction. A • tor or Abettor, Party or Patron to such a Flagicious designement. But Scripture, which is the reflexe of Gods Wisdome, the character of his Will, the scale of his Iustice, and the shining drop of his Goodnesse, doth neither afford Precept nor President to such a horrid practise. Not Precept; for My Son feare God and the King. Prov. 24 21. And I advertise thee to take heed to the mouth of the King. 8 Ecclesi. 2. Let every soule be subject to the higher Powers. Rom. 13.1. Not President; for neither Prophets, Apostles, nor Martyrs, ever gave Example of bearing Arms against their King, no not in the dayes of Ammon, Manasses, Tiberius, Nero, Dioclesian, Julian, Constantius, Constans, Valens, or any other Princes, tainted either with Paganisme or Heresie. And it is very improbable that that Scripture which reproves Rebellion in Heaven, that it should approve of it upon earth; that which reprehended the act of Lucifer, and his traine, for being so taken with their Greatnesse, as that they would not endure a Superior, but for'd up in competition for a parity, yea sought for a Coordination; For I will ascend, and bee like the most High. 14. Isa. 14. That it should countenance the very semblance of the same act amongst men; No, if Lucifer for this was made Noctifer, then Scripture will never make such radiant stars sons of the mornning. Bern.

Secondly, it is not credible that Scripture, which execrates Rebellion in nature (which is generally so stiled, Rom. 7. and stigmatised, because it is a bosome War, a heart-tumult, a mutiny of the affections) that it should tollerate a rebellion in manners, this open Rebellion that comes along with sound of Trumpet, and Banners displayed; if that bee Rebellion because it wants a rectitude, and is an incongruity (which notwithstanding is so privy, that the Eagles eye cannot oftentimes discerne it, not the searching Angell, nor observant Actor, but he that hath eyes ten thousand times brighter than the Sun, must be the close spy) then doubtlesse this practise that so faces God, and dares Scripture, must needs be Rebellion; for from what doth the one borrow the name but from the other?

Thirdly, it were strange that Scripture which dislikes discord (for it cannot scarce endure that a man should have a frown in his brow, or a fret in his brest against his brother) that it should allow Sedition.

Fourthly, that Scripture, which forbids private Murther (even for one man to kill another) that it should suffer an whole Nation to appeare in battle array against their King, and discharge their murthering shot at him: No, it is enough to gather out the sence of Scripture concerning this point, that it equals this sin with that heinous trespasse that hath sold away all right in God, and covenanted with the Divell, Witchcraft 1 Sam. 15.22. and that every where in Scripture, when it comes to aggravate sinne, and to set the notorious mark upon it, that it stiles it Rebellion. 15. Num. 30.26 Num. 9. Deut. 9.2. Iob 24.13. Esai. 41.12. Yea Scripture sufficiently discovers it selfe, that though these Attempters are accounted by the World ennobled Worthies, or grand Assertors of Liberties, yet by Scripture they are esteemed, and named Traytors. 2 Tim. 3.4. Scripture will not allow men to despise Dignities, much lesse to destroy Dignities, not to curse the King in his Bed-chamber, much lesse to assault him in the open field; No, away with this wayward, wretched course, for no plausible shewes, or glorious pretences can wash away the guilt of it; Ye may terme it an Heroick Disposition, a Pious Resolution, but Scripture saith it is to stand in an evill thing. 8 Eccles. 3. Let such therefore take home the sting of the evill to their Consciences, and without an high degree of Humiliation from such a bad Antecedent, expect an evill Consequent, for they shall perish in the gain-saying of Corah, Ep. Iude v, 11. that is some prodigious end, or other, that they might carry the brand of State-troublers in their browes, is designed, and decreed against them; yea, well were it, if they could make a full reckoning with God upon earth, and that by Racks, and Gibbets, and Scaffolds, or some immediate punnishment comming warme out of the hand of the Almighty, they could feel their last of an avenging Iudge, but they shall receive to themselves Damnation.
Rom, 13 2. Oh miserable spark o • Rebellion then that kindles Divine wrath; Yet a reward as certaine as just, for flames to flames, State-flames to Hell-flames. Though they receive nothing upon earth, or they receive much, yet the worst Receipt is behind, they shall receive Damnation; that they which imitate the Devill, and his Angels (as I told you before) shall goe into fire prepared for the Devill and his Angels. And thus I might leave them, that have fetch'd inventions from Hell, at the mouth of Hell, but that they
may shiver the more with the dread of the torment, I will shew them more evidently out of Scripture the manifestnesse of the guilt; for if the sinne be made apparent to them, they know Vengeance lies at the door. That the violent resisting of Princes then is an unquestionable sinne, take these irrefragable Arguments.

1. It is a sinne, because it forsakes Christs State-rule, that unity must be preserved, or casualty is to be expected; For a Kingdom divided against it self cannot stand. Matth. 12.25. Oh then if it be a sinne to overthrow a private Family, to oppresse a man and his house, a man and his heritage, with broad Phylacteries and long Prayers to devour Widows and Orphanes, then what an offence is it to consume a Nation? doubtlesse this is a Piacle scarce to be purged with sacrifice, to be guilty of the Division of a Kingdome in the first place, and the destruction of it in the second place.

2 Cor. 10 4.2. Because it fights not Christs Cause with Christs weapon; for be the designe never so holy, yet the weapons of our Warfore are not carnall; If Doctrine be to be reformed, or Dicipline changed, yet these are to be done by godly Exhortations, not bloody wounds; by judicious conference, not furious combats; for Warres are not lawfull▪ but to maintaine, or recover Titles, and those not by Subjects against their Princes, but by Princes against Vsurpers: I scarce beleeve any moderate and intelligent Divine will justify that Armes are to be taken against Papists, or Turks to propagate Faith. This is none of Christs Warre then, because his proper Engineer is not imployed. Remember that our Saviour sent out his first Disciples without a staffe. Matt. 10.10. and they were to say, Peace be to this House. vers. 12. and remember that the blessed Apostles at their solemne Inauguration into that holy Function, had no double-edged weapons appearing upon them; No, There appeared unto them cloven Tongues. Acts 2.3. Then Ex cijsdem nutrimur ex quibus sumus, if this were Faiths nourishment in the wombe, it may well be her succour at the brest.

3. Because it assaults God in his Vicegerent, for as a man strikes at the Iudge, but meaneth the King; so a man strikes at the King, but he intends God; for a man cannot separate God from the King, because He is the Lords Anointed. Who then can
lay his hand upon the Lords Anointed, and be guiltlesse? Sam. 26.9. Oh beware of sinnes that levell directly at the Almighty; for if one man sinne against another, the Iudge shall judge it, but if a man sinne against the Lord, who shall plead for him. 1 Sam. 2.25.
4. Because it fills a Nation full of all manner of sinnes, as

First Jmpatience, for what are seditious Persons, but Malecontents? men fitter to resist an Ordinance, then to resist a Temptation, to enter into a skirmish, then to endure a Triall; for God must send them such a Governour as they like (and they are very curious in their liking, it is hard for God to provide a dish so delicious, that shall please all palates) or else they will ease their hearts at the swords point: if they c • nnot flee Gods judgement (in shunning such a Prince as they approve not) they will fl e to their weapon. But is this to obey the froward as well as the courteous. 1 Pet. 2.18. No, this is a very querulous obedience.

Secondly Scandall, for the Rebell seldome goes without his complaint ready drawne, he cannot fight till he hath edged his weapons with invectives; Absalons Van-Curriours of his Army were slanders. The matters are good, (saith he) but here is no good King; No, a languishing Government, and lingring Iustice; we are borne to Liberty, but oh under what a heavy bondage doe we live • with these subtill insinuations, and bitter calumnies doth he make David at last to be censured here, and cursed there; all persons that were discontented either for want of Preferment, or for want of Liberty to set the Crowne upon what head they most aff • cted, disgorge upon the Prince. Thus ye see how scandall troubles the State: Subjection speakes with reverence to the Prince, but Rebellion wants her mouth-water, that hath a furred tongue against Authority. And is not this an evill disease? Yes, whats • ev • r the imperfections of the Governour be; yet we should be more mindfull of our owne gifts, Exod. 22.28. then his frailties, for it is a sinne to speake evill of the Ruler of the People.

Thirdly Hypocrisy, For they seem Common-wealths-men, but they are Private-Wealths-men; they pretend suppressing of abuses, but it is supplying of wants; and getting of Priv • ledges to the Subject, but they are preheminences to themselves; they love their King, but they mean his Revenew; and they fight for him, when they discharge at him: Oh is not this delusion and
learning of the State a complementall fiction, a grosse sinne? Yes, we that should speak the truth from our hearts, 15 Psal. 2. and weare sincerity as our Evangelicall girdle, 6 Ephes. 14. doubtless cannot be permitted to be thus versute, and artificiall. No, these publique Larves seem to be of the old race of the Athenians, who with smooth pretences put downe one King, and set up Thirty Tyrants; or of some Iewish Progenie, who gave to their King an Ave, Hayle King of the Iewes, but withall crucified him.

Fourthly Seducing, For the Rebell cannot act all by his single strength; no, he must gather a Party, therefore all his witts are employed after he hath drawn men into discontents, how he may draw them under his banners; so many as follow the King, threaren his head, therefore he must seduce, or give over his projects. And is it not an horrible sinne thus to separate King and People? The Scripture saith, Thou shalt not covet thy Neighbours servant, much lesse then thy Princes Subjects. Was not this the sinne of Absalom, who stole away the hearts of the People of Israel, 2 Sam. 15.6. Stole; Call it what you will, Engaging of the People in the common Cause, confederating them in the holy league, yet it is no other then abominable Theft, yea Felony in the highest degree; for if he that breaks open the Exchequor, or robbs the Mynt, or steales away the Kings Robes, or jewels, commit an high offence, then what doth he that steales away the hearts of his people? they had as good cut off his right hand, or his left, by which he should defend himself.

Fiftly Perjury, For whereas Subjects are the King ligati homines, his Liege men, they have promised to be Loyall and feyall to him, yea they are bounden to him by the greatest assurance upon earth, an Oath; these no sooner enter into Rebellion, but they cancell this assura • ce, and by Associations, and Vows, dejerate, unswear this Oath, as if they would sweare away their God by a contradictory invocation, or renounce an old Oath by a new Covenant; a strange kind of dispensation, an heterogeneous Absolution; yet thus they abuse Gods Name, chevalrise Conscience, and that which is worst of all, insnare a Kingdome in a woefull curse; they have taken their hands from the Bible, where tactis Evangelijs, they did pronounce, all their comforts lay, and they have forfeited Gods helpe, which upon this condition they
did insure to their soules, and they have untitled themselves 〈◊〉 all the priviledges of Faith, and merits of a pretious Redemption, which were to be conveighed unto them upon their fidelity; and indeed by this impious course they remaine but as a botch to Profession, a selfe-soules-fret, and a daily object of divine vengeance. Perjury is so greivous a sinne, that it is generally called by the name of Blasphemy (nay a vaine Oath is so, much more then a false Oath) and commonly Divines hold it a species of the sins against the Holy-Ghost; for can theere be almost a greater sin, than to set ones mouth against Heaven, and defy vengeance, to seem to have sworn to a deafe, impotent, or an imaginary God? surely they have a weak perswasion of a God, little feeling of a soule, or dread of Doomesday, that make no Conscience of an Oath; therefore Salomon frights the Subject from the least act of Disloyalty, and that because of the Oath of God. 8. Eccl. 2.

Sixtly Cruelty, for when Rebellion comes, what comes, but for every one to rage upon his next neighbours, and to eat as it were the flesh of his own arme? The Rebell is another Ishmael, his hand against every man, and every mans hand against him. 16. Gen. 12. he hath sworn the destruction of his Country, and he careth not by what outrages he doth effect it, he knowes hee cannot work his ends by high lookes, or dry-blows, and therefore he breatheth nothing but slaughters, and layes on none but brayning-blowes; all his delight is to dazle here, and cleave there, and to leave nothing behind him but scattered skuls, and shattered ribs; these are his pleasing spectacles, his glorious Trophees: And can there be a wilder beast upon earth than the Blood-sucker? who envyes every mans life, and fights for no other end, but to kill, and that every place might carry some prints of his terror, and marks of his fury; when there is no noise heard in the land but that no man spareth his Brother, and that hee snatcheth at the right-hand and is hungry, and eate • on the left-hand and is not satisfied. 9. Es. 20. Or, Woe is me now, for my soule fainteth because of the Murtherers. Now if Blood-shed carry any guilt in it, what is here but a Sinne of the deepest dy? The Rebell cannot subsist, but by filling all places full of dread, and death.

Seventhly Malice; for canst thou love him that stretcheth
out his hand to take thee Captive, or brandish his sword to shed thy blood? That hath no other name for thee but Malignant, and is ready to execute thee (for thy duty to God and the King) as a Delinquent? Oh will not such griefes stick and fester within, especially when thy brother hath kild that mans sonne, or that mans Nephew hath kild thy Father? Yes, as the Duke of Savoy said of the Lord Crequi for sl • ying his noble Brother Anthony, that there was no Attonement to be made, because the blood of Anthony was not yet dry upon Crequies sword. Blood will have a restlesse cry for revenge, insomuch that when the heate of the Wars are over, yet God knowes when the spight of the cause, an • the malice of the Warres will end: Now Rebellion, that raises up s • ch unkind distasts, an • causes such a setled rancor in a Nation, must it not needs be a trespasse of an high nature? Yes, they that sowe discord • , and separate very friends, as Solomon saith, have ever been held deeply culpable. I say no more, but Offences may come, but woe bee to them by whom the Offence commeth.

Thus then ye see how Scriptures accurse these Wars; for the Bible hath been opened before you, and ye have heard how God upon his own Throne hath pronounced sentence against them. What now then, hath God written unto you the great things of his Law, and sh • ll they be unto you as a strange thing? Will ye stop your eares at the voice of the Charmer, charme he never so wisely? Ye which have seemed these many yeares to have been Bible-circled, will ye now trample the Bibles under your feet? Shall Gods will revealed be as a Trumpet that gives an uncertaine sound? Or shall the rule of Obedience now be cried down as a false square? Shall men presume above that which is written, and adde to this full Revelation? Would you have the purity of the Ordinances restored, and leave another Ordinance (Rom. 13.2.) in her unclean blood? Did God know Christians should have supreame Governours, and hath he provided so for obedience to their calling, that there must be such trying of it out at the sh • r • , to resolve Subjects scruples about their necessary duty? No, God which is the God of Order, and not confusion, hath setled every thing to them that are willing to receive satisfaction. They which runne to great Counsellors, or armed Souldiers, for a clearer interpretation, are as ill satisfied
with their God, as their King. Oh then draw not a sword, lest ye fight against your received Principles, that the Word of God hath all things in it necessary for faith and manners; war not against Scripture, lest you war without booke. It will bee hard for you to kick against the pricks; this stone upon whomsoever it shall fall, it will grind him all to pieces; God hath set before you life and death; by these words ye must be judged at the last day. Oh therefore, I beseech you by all the reverence you beare to Scripture, by the soules check which you carry in your bosomes, that there is only to be found the infallible truth, by the infinite obligations it layes upon you for lowly, and loyall demeanor to Superiours, that ye end all these troublesome, and pernicious courses. If the Scripture command you to feare your King, turne not his feare into a fray; if that command you to honour him, turne not his honour into horror; if ye must needs be subject for Conscience sake, then either yeeld subjection, or deny a Conscience; if ye must submit for the Lords sake, then for the Lords sake expresse no more turbulencies. Oh beautifie Profession with the ancient Moderation, Patience, Fidelity, and Loyalty that belongs to Subjects; let those Primitive Professors tread out the way to you, rather than these post • nati, new seeds-men of Sedition. Come before your Prince therefore with bended knees, rather than with stiffe hearts, with naked breasts than naked swords, with cleare protestations of duty, rather than bright harnesse; know how a King is to be encountred, how to be conquered; remember your Christian discipline, your religious postures; let Scripture teach you your seates of Armes, let the Bible be your Military direction, let this advise you how to hold a Councell of Warre, how to fetch home a King to Parliament. For Scriptures sake then, do not divide the Kingdome any further, lest you un-Nation it; do not take up Armes for Religion, when Religion requires no such Artillery, fight not against your King, lest you fight against your God; adorne your Country with the lustre of a Christian obedience, rather than blemish it with the skars of Impatience, Scandall, Hipocrisie, Seducing, Perjury, Cruelty, Malice. Oh therefore search Scripture, and submit to Scripture, and then ye cannot but submit to your King; ye must not encrease your bands, when Scripture bids you disband, ye must not list more Forces, when Scripture
bids you break up the Camp; if God will have you to be quiet, resist not; if he bid you lay down your Arms, renew not a stroak; be but as obedient as Scripture counsailes you, and the insurrection ceases; let the Militia go where Scripture hath setled it, and the sword is restored to the right hand. Oh then if the Scripture have any power over you, the King shall not have a Subject to oppose him, no the Warres shall cease, for Scripture h • th decreed them unlawfull.

Ye have now seen then how Nature, Policy and Scripture disavow the action, Nature trembles at it, Policy stands agast at it, Scripture damnes it; Shall not this triple tye be able to knit a divided Nation in a firme union? yes, a threefold cord is not easily broken. Oh then consult with the tender natures in your owne bosomes, consult with Policy the home-bred States-man in your own brayns, consult with Scripture, the oracle of your own souls, and lot these three powerful Monitors prevaile with you to stint these dismall outrages. Consider when ye have harassed your Country, and massacred your brethren sufficiently; consider how many decayed men lament your discord, how many dismembred men detest your fury; consider how many ye have chased from their families, how many ye have mured up in loathsome prisons; consider how many broken walls, and dead bones ye have left behinde you; consider what an inlet ye have caused to sinne, what a stack ye have put to Iustice; consider what desperate Doctrines ye have suffered to be vented in the pulpit, and what dangerous Schismes ye have permitted to spread in the Church, consider what foreigne Protestants ye have left destitute of ayde, nay how ye have given occasion to your Neighbour-Professors to lay open to the edge of the sword; consider how ye have animated discontented men of your owne Religion to trouble their naturall Princes, nay armed the Iesuites to raise tumults in Christian States; consider how the Country begins to want money to satisfy your wants, and blood to spill in your quarrell; consider how many soules ye have troubled, and how many consciences distressed about these garboyles; consider what account ye will give to after-times for these proceedings, and what a heavy reckoning remains for you at Gods Iudgement seat. Consider what I have said, and the Lord give you understanding; And if there be any feare of the Divine Maiesty, any reverence to supreame
Authority, any honour to Gods revealed will, any obedience to Lawes established, any remorse for sinne, any dread of vengeance, any love to your Country that bred you, any respect to your brethren, who though they cannot yeeld a consent to you, yet challenge an equall right with you in all the Priviledges of the Nation, if any pitty, sympathy, bowells of compassion to the groanes of the scattered multitude, or to the sorrowfull sighing of prisoners, to the dismantled Walls, or dismembred lims, to the miseries of the tradesman, or the exigents of the husbandman, to the irruptions of sin, or interuptions of Iustice, to the eclypse of the light of the Gospel, or the distempering of Order, to the disadvantage of friends, or advantage of enemies, to the wounded hearts, or afflicted soules, to your fames, or to your posterities, to the preserving of your lives upon earth, or the saving of your soules in the day of the Lord Iesus, now in the midst of fears and frights, tears and curses, wants and wounds forragings & plunderings, weakning of goodnesse, and strengthning of sinne, emptying of Hamlets, and filling of Garrisons, disturbing of Trade, and dispeopling of a Country, scorne of Tribunalls, and contempt of pulpit, mercilesnesse towards your brethren, and undutifulness towards your Soveraigne; at last recollect your selves, make a faire pause, rebate your edge, pacifie your rage, consider how the Critticall day of this violent feaver is come upon us, behold how the surges rise, and the Ancho s come home, and the ship leaks, and many thousands are ready to give out their last scrike for pitty-digitis à morte remoti, quatuor aut septem.— Oh therefore kindle not more fires to consume the rest of the building, sacrifice not more mens lives to the Goddesse Fury, but if ye have any sight or foresight to discerne approaching miseries, behold how the whole Kingdome is ready to turn Bancrupt, and the vitall spirits evaporating by too deep a cut in the Arteries: Oh doe not the leane Kine eate up the fatt? Doe not the servants ride on horseback, and the Masters at home of high birth, perhaps Noble extraction have scarce a Palfry to mount? Is not the power of the whole Kingdome generally put into the hands of spend-rhrifts? Is not the Common safety in the hands of doubtfull Keepers? Are ye not in as much feare of discontents, as of a set battell? Can a Parliament Vote, or the Absolution of a Synod f ••• yo • of
all these hazzards? Stand ye not in slippery places? Doe not the sides of the hou • e crack, and the splinters fly about, and the very Foundation give way, as if all would ere long fall into rubble and ashes? Oh will ye never apprehend danger, till a Non putâram come in; I would never have thought there would have been such an accident? Are ye so dazled with the brightnesse of your present Designe, that ye cannot, or will not see any thing but in an eclypse? There have been many hints already; warnings will not alwayes be given. If ye doe not respect your selves, why doe ye not tender those many thousands whom ye have brought into the compasse of the net with you? Would it not grieve any ingenuous Nature to thinke that He, or He should be the cause of inthralling so many willing, u • willing Wretches, which doe obey, bec • use ye pronounce it Obedience, or doe obey, because they must obey? Howsoever if they and you, and many thousands more should double and redouble your courages, that the Warres may goe on, and the sword not be laid downe so long as there be left a hilt to fight with, yet what are ye doing, but bringing misery to confusion? Our breach is great like the sea, make it a little wider, and there will be nothing but a Deluge to be seen: Destruction upon destruction is cryed, our tents will be destroyed, and our curtaines in a moment. 4 Jer. 20.
Behold one evill is come, an evill is come, yea an end is come, an end is come. 7 Ezech. 6.

The land begins to be empty, and void, and waste, the heart melteth, the knees knock together, sorrow is in all loynes, and all faces gather blacknesse.2 Nah. 10. There is a little remnant of comfort yet left, deprive us not of this, lest ye deprive us of all; No, doe with it, as with the wine found in the cluster, destroy it not for for a blessing is in it. 65. Es. 8. All the blessing that is left unto us after this great vintage of sorrows.
Oh therefore make a speedy end, for feare of a speedy Ruine; Doe that now, which ye cannot doe alwayes.

Now, or never therefore, Let us be beholding to you for your passionate sight of our extremities, for your compassionate
sense of our dangers, for your wise fore-sight of ensuing Ruth, for your grave Counsayle to prevent all mischiefs; Oh at last heare Nature, listen to Policy, and be advised by Scripture, that ye may cleerly see, seriously lay to heart, and uprightly determine how Formidable and Fatall, miserable and Execrable, unnaturall and unlawfull these Warres are.
